Dari autem potest tutor non solum pater familias, sed etiam filius familias. Sed et servus proprius testamentol cum libertate recte tutor dari potest. sed sciendum est eum et sine libertate tutorem datum tacite et libertatem directam

§4 Postumi liberi are children born after the execution of the will: whether aster the death of the testator or in his life-time is immaterial. Α paterfamilias could not give a testamentary guardian to a posthumous grandson, if, supposing be had died immediately after the execution of the will, the grandson would have been born in the potestas of his own father, the testator's son: for in that case, the father being in the same potestas, the child would not have been a suus heres to the testator. Guardianship was only intended as a substitute for patria potestas, and the existence of the latter barred the possibility of the former.

§ 6. There were five other cases in which magisterial confirmation of a testamentary appointment was required, viz. (ι) where a father gave by will a guardian to his natural child, Dig. 26. 3. 73 (2) where the ap- pointment vas made in unconfirmed codicils or in an invalid will, Dig. ib. 1.t; (3) where the appointment violated the SC. Libonianum by being written by the guardian himself3 here a ‘praevia inquisitio' was neees- sary, Dig. ib. 2. 29: 48. 10.18. 13 (4) where a mother attempted to give a testamentary guardian to her child, the appointment would be confirmed only ‘ex inquisitione,' and only if the child were instituted heir in the vill, Dig. ib. 24 ; (5) if a man appointed a testamentary guardian to the child of some other person, the appointment would be confirmed ex inquisitione if the child were instituted heir in the will, and had no other property, Dig. ib. 3. 4. 5. ln all these cases, or at any rate . where an inquisitio was held, the appointment was deemed magisteria! rather than testamentary, Dig. ib. 2. 26. 2: 48. ro.18. 1.
